H0.text: Erode is what the surrounding rock will do when an igneous intrusion comes into contact with it.

H1.text: Foliate is what the surrounding rock will do when an igneous intrusion comes into contact with it.

H2.text: Precipitate is the process that the surrounding rock will undergo when an igneous intrusion comes into contact with it.

H3.text: Recrystallize is what the surrounding rock does when an igneous intrusion comes into contact with it.

A4.text: Rocks formed by contact metamorphism may not present signs of strong deformation and are often fine-grained and extremely tough.

A6.text: Foliations in the intrusion and the surrounding country rock are roughly parallel, indicating extreme deformation in the country rock.

A7.text: Hot fluids circulating through pore space in the rock can dissolve existing minerals and precipitate new minerals.

A8.text: The formation of important ore minerals may occur by the process of metasomatism at or near the contact zone.
